values.description:
Two commits in this branch:
 - Set up the new mode RelWithDebInfo adding the -g and -O2
 - Change Release mode to use -O3

Important! if no mode was supplied to the cmake script, it is going to default to Release mode. We should think if this is the desired approach. If it is, we should made jenkins to pass the RelWithDebInfo to cmake.
values.title: Support for cmake mode RelWithDebInfo

summary.raw:
Two commits in this branch:
 - Set up the new mode RelWithDebInfo adding the -g and -O2
 - Change Release mode to use -O3

Important! if no mode was supplied to the cmake script, it is going to default to Release mode. We should think if this is the desired approach. If it is, we should made jenkins to pass the RelWithDebInfo to cmake.
summary.html:
Two commits in this branch: - Set up the new mode RelWithDebInfo adding the -g and -O2 - Change Release mode to use -O3

Important! if no mode was supplied to the cmake script, it is going to default to Release mode. We should think if this is the desired approach. If it is, we should made jenkins to pass the RelWithDebInfo to cmake.

values.description:
Test case:

1. Remote server

1. Client machine has two non-loopback interfaces, and the second is used to communicate with the server.

1. If the client does not specify the appropriate GAZEBO_IP, the server will hang when trying to establish a connection.

Solution:

Use a `timed_wait` in Connection.cc.

Other goodies:

I added a message during startup that outputs the publicized IP address.
values.title: Remote server will hang if client uses and IP address that cannot be reached by the server.

summary.raw:
Test case:

1. Remote server

1. Client machine has two non-loopback interfaces, and the second is used to communicate with the server.

1. If the client does not specify the appropriate GAZEBO_IP, the server will hang when trying to establish a connection.

Solution:

Use a `timed_wait` in Connection.cc.

Other goodies:

I added a message during startup that outputs the publicized IP address.
summary.html:
Test case:

  1. Remote server

  2. Client machine has two non-loopback interfaces, and the second is used to communicate with the server.

  3. If the client does not specify the appropriate GAZEBO_IP, the server will hang when trying to establish a connection.

Solution:

Use a timed_wait in Connection.cc.

Other goodies:

I added a message during startup that outputs the publicized IP address.

values.description:
The message factory creates message based on a string type. This is useful when creating a subscriber that can switch between many different topics. This type of subscriber can query the message type for the topic, and decode the raw data appropriately. 

This is needed for sensor visualization in the GUI (which will be a future pull request).
values.title: Added a message factory

summary.raw:
The message factory creates message based on a string type. This is useful when creating a subscriber that can switch between many different topics. This type of subscriber can query the message type for the topic, and decode the raw data appropriately. 

This is needed for sensor visualization in the GUI (which will be a future pull request).
summary.html:
The message factory creates message based on a string type. This is useful when creating a subscriber that can switch between many different topics. This type of subscriber can query the message type for the topic, and decode the raw data appropriately.

This is needed for sensor visualization in the GUI (which will be a future pull request).

values.description:
I found this bug while testing bullet. I think this is a reasonable fix. As written, it will print to gzdbg whenever a world is loaded by ServerFixture. Also, it will wait for 30 seconds for the world to load and then exit the test if it has not loaded properly in that time. 

I also added a timeout to the loop at lines 120-121 of ServerFixture.hh.
values.title: Fix for issue #334: ServerFixture load paused bug

summary.raw:
I found this bug while testing bullet. I think this is a reasonable fix. As written, it will print to gzdbg whenever a world is loaded by ServerFixture. Also, it will wait for 30 seconds for the world to load and then exit the test if it has not loaded properly in that time. 

I also added a timeout to the loop at lines 120-121 of ServerFixture.hh.
summary.html:
I found this bug while testing bullet. I think this is a reasonable fix. As written, it will print to gzdbg whenever a world is loaded by ServerFixture. Also, it will wait for 30 seconds for the world to load and then exit the test if it has not loaded properly in that time.

I also added a timeout to the loop at lines 120-121 of ServerFixture.hh.

values.description:
This patch moves the EmptyWorld bullet test into physics.cc and runs the test on both ODE and bullet by specifying different sdf files. We can easily add simbody and RTQL8 tests when the time arises.

Note that the EmptyWorld tests currently give a warning:
~~~
Warning [World.cc:441] Calling World::StepWorld(steps) while world is not paused
~~~

This warning is related to issue #334 and should be fixed by pull request #211.
values.title: Test physics engines together

summary.raw:
This patch moves the EmptyWorld bullet test into physics.cc and runs the test on both ODE and bullet by specifying different sdf files. We can easily add simbody and RTQL8 tests when the time arises.

Note that the EmptyWorld tests currently give a warning:
~~~
Warning [World.cc:441] Calling World::StepWorld(steps) while world is not paused
~~~

This warning is related to issue #334 and should be fixed by pull request #211.
summary.html:
This patch moves the EmptyWorld bullet test into physics.cc and runs the test on both ODE and bullet by specifying different sdf files. We can easily add simbody and RTQL8 tests when the time arises.

Note that the EmptyWorld tests currently give a warning:

Warning [World.cc:441] Calling World::StepWorld(steps) while world is not paused

This warning is related to issue #334 and should be fixed by pull request #211.

values.description:
This pull request incorporates GUI topic viewers. A generic text viewer acts like `gztopic echo`. A camera viewer displays camera images. There is a place holder for a laser viewer (note that LaserView.* is not actually compiled right now).

You can launch a viewer from within Gazebo using CTRL-T to bring up the topic selector, or via the Window menu item.

You can also launch a viewer from the command line using either:

* `gztopic view` to bring up the topic selector, or
* `gztopic view <topic_name>` to bring up a viewer for the specified topic.
values.title: New sensor visualization GUI interfaces

summary.raw:
This pull request incorporates GUI topic viewers. A generic text viewer acts like `gztopic echo`. A camera viewer displays camera images. There is a place holder for a laser viewer (note that LaserView.* is not actually compiled right now).

You can launch a viewer from within Gazebo using CTRL-T to bring up the topic selector, or via the Window menu item.

You can also launch a viewer from the command line using either:

* `gztopic view` to bring up the topic selector, or
* `gztopic view <topic_name>` to bring up a viewer for the specified topic.
summary.html:
This pull request incorporates GUI topic viewers. A generic text viewer acts like gztopic echo. A camera viewer displays camera images. There is a place holder for a laser viewer (note that LaserView.* is not actually compiled right now).

You can launch a viewer from within Gazebo using CTRL-T to bring up the topic selector, or via the Window menu item.

You can also launch a viewer from the command line using either:

  • gztopic view to bring up the topic selector, or
  • gztopic view <topic_name> to bring up a viewer for the specified topic.

values.description:
This patch will save the current user camera angle when saving a world file and fixes issue #265. This requires parsing the world file generated by the server and inserting the user camera data into a gui element. There's also a minor style fix in the physics test.

I have not included a test because I'm not aware of a way to test gzclient. My test procedure would be the following:

1. Load a world
2. Change the user camera pose
3. Save world as a different file name
4. Verify that saved file has different and correct user camera pose
values.title: Issue #265: save user camera angle when saving world files

I have not included a test because I'm not aware of a way to test gzclient. My test procedure would be the following:

  1. Load a world
  2. Change the user camera pose
  3. Save world as a different file name
  4. Verify that saved file has different and correct user camera pose

values.description:
The code changes in this pull request are driven by the SpawnDrop test that is added to `test/regression/physics.cc`. This test spawns a box, sphere, and cylinder and drops them onto a static ground plane. It tests the free-fall phase, in which:

* x,y positions should not be changing
* z position should be decreasing
* x,y velocities should be zero
* z velocity should be negative

It also tests a resting contact phase, in which:

* all velocities should be near zero
* x,y position should be near their initial values
* the z position of the bottom of each object should be near the ground plane

The SpawnDropODE test passes, and the SpawnDropBullet test almost passes. It currently fails one of the EXPECTS, because the box and cylinder bounce to the side when they hit the ground. John and I think that this is a parameter issue in the bullet solver, and we're planning to address it. I'm creating a ticket for that issue.

Output of SpawnDropBullet test:
~~~
[ RUN      ] PhysicsTest.SpawnDropBullet
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 1.4.0
Copyright (C) 2012 Nate Koenig, John Hsu, and contributors.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org

Msg Waiting for master
Msg Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
Msg Publicized address: 192.168.1.67
Dbg Check freefall of model test_box
Dbg Check freefall of model test_sphere
Dbg Check freefall of model test_cylinder
Dbg Check ground contact of model test_box
Dbg Check ground contact of model test_sphere
Dbg Check ground contact of model test_cylinder
/home/scpeters/osrf/gazebo/test/regression/physics.cc:174: Failure
The difference between pose1.pos.x and x0 is 0.010209083557128906, which exceeds 1e-2, where
pose1.pos.x evaluates to 8.0102090835571289,
x0 evaluates to 8, and
1e-2 evaluates to 0.01.
[  FAILED  ] PhysicsTest.SpawnDropBullet (3065 ms)
~~~
values.title: Bullet integration: spawn and drop simple shapes

summary.raw:
The code changes in this pull request are driven by the SpawnDrop test that is added to `test/regression/physics.cc`. This test spawns a box, sphere, and cylinder and drops them onto a static ground plane. It tests the free-fall phase, in which:

* x,y positions should not be changing
* z position should be decreasing
* x,y velocities should be zero
* z velocity should be negative

It also tests a resting contact phase, in which:

* all velocities should be near zero
* x,y position should be near their initial values
* the z position of the bottom of each object should be near the ground plane

The SpawnDropODE test passes, and the SpawnDropBullet test almost passes. It currently fails one of the EXPECTS, because the box and cylinder bounce to the side when they hit the ground. John and I think that this is a parameter issue in the bullet solver, and we're planning to address it. I'm creating a ticket for that issue.

summary.html:
The code changes in this pull request are driven by the SpawnDrop test that is added to test/regression/physics.cc. This test spawns a box, sphere, and cylinder and drops them onto a static ground plane. It tests the free-fall phase, in which:

  • x,y positions should not be changing
  • z position should be decreasing
  • x,y velocities should be zero
  • z velocity should be negative

It also tests a resting contact phase, in which:

  • all velocities should be near zero
  • x,y position should be near their initial values
  • the z position of the bottom of each object should be near the ground plane

The SpawnDropODE test passes, and the SpawnDropBullet test almost passes. It currently fails one of the EXPECTS, because the box and cylinder bounce to the side when they hit the ground. John and I think that this is a parameter issue in the bullet solver, and we're planning to address it. I'm creating a ticket for that issue.

Output of SpawnDropBullet test:

[ RUN      ] PhysicsTest.SpawnDropBullet
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 1.4.0
Copyright (C) 2012 Nate Koenig, John Hsu, and contributors.
Released under the Apache 2 License.

values.description:
Make the simbody cmake target depending on the msgs (like the rest of the targets).

This seems to fix the problem (race condition) when building the simbody branch and trying to compile simbody code before msgs were generated.

values.description:
Often when I spawn a hokuyo in the environment, its laser scan is not rendered, typically the first hokuyo in a given gazebo session. Latching the "~/sensor" message seems to fix it for me.

If we had a way to test gzclient, I would do the following:

1. Load an empty world `gazebo`.
2. Click insert model, select hokuyo, and place it somewhere on the ground plane.
3. Verify that it draws its laser scan.
4. Repeat several times from a fresh instance of `gazebo`.
values.title: First spawned hokuyo doesn't always have rendered laser scan

summary.raw:
Often when I spawn a hokuyo in the environment, its laser scan is not rendered, typically the first hokuyo in a given gazebo session. Latching the "~/sensor" message seems to fix it for me.

If we had a way to test gzclient, I would do the following:

1. Load an empty world `gazebo`.
2. Click insert model, select hokuyo, and place it somewhere on the ground plane.
3. Verify that it draws its laser scan.
4. Repeat several times from a fresh instance of `gazebo`.
summary.html:
Often when I spawn a hokuyo in the environment, its laser scan is not rendered, typically the first hokuyo in a given gazebo session. Latching the "~/sensor" message seems to fix it for me.

If we had a way to test gzclient, I would do the following:

  1. Load an empty world gazebo.
  2. Click insert model, select hokuyo, and place it somewhere on the ground plane.
  3. Verify that it draws its laser scan.
  4. Repeat several times from a fresh instance of gazebo.

values.description:
A material script may need multiple URIs, for example:

    <material>
      <script>
        <uri>file://location_of_a_material_script</uri>
        <uri>file://location_of_a_texture_used_by_the_material_script</uri>
      <script>
    </material>

This will also allow a model in the model database to use a script from one model and a texture file from a different model.
values.title: Allow multiple uri elements for a material script

summary.raw:
A material script may need multiple URIs, for example:

    <material>
      <script>
        <uri>file://location_of_a_material_script</uri>
        <uri>file://location_of_a_texture_used_by_the_material_script</uri>
      <script>
    </material>

This will also allow a model in the model database to use a script from one model and a texture file from a different model.
summary.html:
A material script may need multiple URIs, for example:

<material>
  <script>
    <uri>file://location_of_a_material_script</uri>
    <uri>file://location_of_a_texture_used_by_the_material_script</uri>
  <script>
</material>

This will also allow a model in the model database to use a script from one model and a texture file from a different model.

values.description:
Initial support for function GZ_ASSERT which will handle assertions inside gazebo.

Actions done:
* Make GZ_ASSERT as name for BOOST_ASSERT_MSG
* Define an exception class inheritance: InternalError and AssertionInternalError. Altough it is not used at the moment, can represent all kind of internal errors which need to throw an exception. AssertionInternalError is for internal errors generated by assertions.  
* Define functions to throw AssertionInternalError when BOOST_ENABLE_ASSERT_HANDLER is enabled.
* Testing for all the components (testing directory and structure need a reorganization, at this moment is hosts in unit/common).
values.title: Initial support for assertions: GZ_ASSERT

summary.raw:
Initial support for function GZ_ASSERT which will handle assertions inside gazebo.

Actions done:
* Make GZ_ASSERT as name for BOOST_ASSERT_MSG
* Define an exception class inheritance: InternalError and AssertionInternalError. Altough it is not used at the moment, can represent all kind of internal errors which need to throw an exception. AssertionInternalError is for internal errors generated by assertions.  
* Define functions to throw AssertionInternalError when BOOST_ENABLE_ASSERT_HANDLER is enabled.
* Testing for all the components (testing directory and structure need a reorganization, at this moment is hosts in unit/common).
summary.html:
Initial support for function GZ_ASSERT which will handle assertions inside gazebo.

Actions done: Make GZ_ASSERT as name for BOOST_ASSERT_MSG Define an exception class inheritance: InternalError and AssertionInternalError. Altough it is not used at the moment, can represent all kind of internal errors which need to throw an exception. AssertionInternalError is for internal errors generated by assertions.
Define functions to throw AssertionInternalError when BOOST_ENABLE_ASSERT_HANDLER is enabled. Testing for all the components (testing directory and structure need a reorganization, at this moment is hosts in unit/common).

values.description:
This pull request fixes the collada importer. A forthcoming pull request to the model database relies on this.

I also tried to fix a shadow bug. Instead of a complete solution, I turned down the intensity of shadows. A lot of cg and hlsl cruft has also been removed from the rtshaderlib directory. These scripts were never used.
values.title: Collada and Shadows

summary.raw:
This pull request fixes the collada importer. A forthcoming pull request to the model database relies on this.

I also tried to fix a shadow bug. Instead of a complete solution, I turned down the intensity of shadows. A lot of cg and hlsl cruft has also been removed from the rtshaderlib directory. These scripts were never used.
summary.html:
This pull request fixes the collada importer. A forthcoming pull request to the model database relies on this.

I also tried to fix a shadow bug. Instead of a complete solution, I turned down the intensity of shadows. A lot of cg and hlsl cruft has also been removed from the rtshaderlib directory. These scripts were never used.

summary.html: The sdf::Element::Update function was updating attributes but not element values. This patch includes a test that failed as of changeset a8abb5f, and a fix.

values.description:
Renames the two types of manifest.xml files from:

  1) Database `manifest.xml` to `database.config`

  2) Model `manifest.xml` to `model.config`

The model database has already been updated.

This change is backward compatible.
values.title: Renaming model database manifest files

values.description:
The main feature of this pull request is a fix for bullet's revolute joint (BulletHingeJoint) so that it passes the same pendulum test as ODE (SimplePendulumTest). I did have to tweak the inertial parameters slightly in simple_pendulums_bullet.world, changing inertia values from 0 to 1e-6, so it does differ insubstantially from the ODE test.

I also made a few static functions in BulletTypes for converting between gazebo and bullet Vector3 and poses.

I filled in the BulletLink::OnPoseChange, so that Reset Model Poses, Reset World, and the move/rotate tools work.

I fixed a bug in the processing of physics messages, so the update rate, step size, and gravity can be adjusted from the gui.

I also added Link::GetWorldCoGPose, which is useful since the bullet functions define everything relative to the center of gravity of a rigid body.

I also added a SpawnDropCoG test, which spawns several spheres of different radii and different center of gravity locations. It's currently failing; I believe it is related to physics engine parameters, which will be addressed in a future pull request. I've added the failing tests to the description of issue #349.

UPDATE:
Ian figured out what was causing the SpawnDrop tests to fail, so now there is only one portion of the tests that fails, related to issue #376.
values.title: Bullet integration: simple pendulum

summary.raw:
The main feature of this pull request is a fix for bullet's revolute joint (BulletHingeJoint) so that it passes the same pendulum test as ODE (SimplePendulumTest). I did have to tweak the inertial parameters slightly in simple_pendulums_bullet.world, changing inertia values from 0 to 1e-6, so it does differ insubstantially from the ODE test.

I also made a few static functions in BulletTypes for converting between gazebo and bullet Vector3 and poses.

I filled in the BulletLink::OnPoseChange, so that Reset Model Poses, Reset World, and the move/rotate tools work.

I fixed a bug in the processing of physics messages, so the update rate, step size, and gravity can be adjusted from the gui.

I also added Link::GetWorldCoGPose, which is useful since the bullet functions define everything relative to the center of gravity of a rigid body.

I also added a SpawnDropCoG test, which spawns several spheres of different radii and different center of gravity locations. It's currently failing; I believe it is related to physics engine parameters, which will be addressed in a future pull request. I've added the failing tests to the description of issue #349.

UPDATE:
Ian figured out what was causing the SpawnDrop tests to fail, so now there is only one portion of the tests that fails, related to issue #376.
summary.html:
The main feature of this pull request is a fix for bullet's revolute joint (BulletHingeJoint) so that it passes the same pendulum test as ODE (SimplePendulumTest). I did have to tweak the inertial parameters slightly in simple_pendulums_bullet.world, changing inertia values from 0 to 1e-6, so it does differ insubstantially from the ODE test.

I also made a few static functions in BulletTypes for converting between gazebo and bullet Vector3 and poses.

I filled in the BulletLink::OnPoseChange, so that Reset Model Poses, Reset World, and the move/rotate tools work.

I fixed a bug in the processing of physics messages, so the update rate, step size, and gravity can be adjusted from the gui.

I also added Link::GetWorldCoGPose, which is useful since the bullet functions define everything relative to the center of gravity of a rigid body.

I also added a SpawnDropCoG test, which spawns several spheres of different radii and different center of gravity locations. It's currently failing; I believe it is related to physics engine parameters, which will be addressed in a future pull request. I've added the failing tests to the description of issue #349.

UPDATE: Ian figured out what was causing the SpawnDrop tests to fail, so now there is only one portion of the tests that fails, related to issue #376.

values.description:
Using pkg_config method if cmake failed.

As a side effect, this will allow us not to change our current scripts and documentation, see #!/osrf/gazebo-release/issue/20/fix-support-for-looking-ros-related
values.title: Support for checking for ros software using pkg_config if cmake method fails
